sect2.title: What is Guava?
sect2.para: Google Guava is a collection of simple core Java libraries used at Google. It is a collection of utility classes and static methods reminiscent of the Apache Commons components discussed in previous chapters.

sect2.title: Problem
sect2.para: You need to use Google Guava in a project.

sect2.title: Solution
sect2.para: To use Google Guava in a Maven 2 project, add the following dependency to your project's pom.xml:

example.title: Adding a Dependency on Google Guava

sect2.para: If you are not sure what this means, I'd suggest reading Maven: The Complete Reference. When you depend on a library in Maven 2, all you need to do is add the dependency groupId, artifactId, and version to your project's dependencies. Once you do this, Maven 2 will download the dependency and make it available on your project's classpath.

sect2.title: See Also
sect2.para: For more information about the Google Guava project, see the project page at http://code.google.com/p/guava-libraries/.

sect2.title: Problem
sect2.para: You want to combine multiple InputStreams into a single InputStream.

sect2.title: Solution
sect2.para: Create new InputSuppliers from files using Files.newInputStreamSupplier(), create an OutputSupplier using Files.newOutputStreamSupplier, join the InputSupplier instances using ByteStreams.join(), and then copy the combined InputSupplier to the OutputSupplier using ByteStreams.copy().

example.title: Joining Two Files using ByteStreams.join() and ByteStreams.copy()

sect2.title: Problem
sect2.para: You need to concatenate the contents of one or more Readers. In this case, you need to append the contents of two files, and you want to use Readers and Writers to take into account the character sets of the files.

sect2.title: Solution
sect2.para: Use Files.newReaderSupplier() to create two InputSuppliers. Pass these InputSuppliers to CharStreams.join(). Create an OutputSupplier using Files.newWriterSupplier(), and then use CharStreams.copy() to copy the InputSupplier to the OutputSupplier.

example.title: Joining Two Readers using CharStreams.join() and CharStreams.copy()

sect2.title: Problem
sect2.para: You need to read a particular region of an InputStream. Maybe you have an in-memory byte array and you only need to read a particular portion of this array, or maybe you need to read information from a binary file, skipping an unimportant preamble.

sect2.title: Solution
sect2.para: Use ByteStreams.slice() to slice an InputSupplier. When you slice an InputSupplier, you create a new InputSupplier which will return an InputStream that contains a specified portion of the underlying stream.

example.title: Slicing Data from an InputStream

sect2.title: Discussion
sect2.para: The last two arguments to the slice method are: offset, the number of bytes into the underlying stream to start the newly sliced stream and the maximum number of bytes to return from this newly sliced stream.

sect1.title: Flushing and Closing Stream, Writer, or Reader (without the Headache of Exception Handling)

sect2.title: Problem
sect2.para: You are constantly having to close and flush streams and you would like to avoid having to catch IOException.

sect2.title: Solution
sect2.para: Use Closeables and Flushables. Here's an example of opening and writing a single byte to a file without the help of any convenience methods from a library like Google Guava or Apache Commons.

example.title: One of the Reasons Java Gets a Bad Rap

sect2.para: Forget the exception handling outside of the finally block (which is already distracting). If you trying to flush and close the OutputStream in a finally block you are in for a surprise. Since flush() and close() throw an IOException, your finally block has to have a nested try/catch block. While there may be someone, somewhere who is appreciative of the fact that flush() throws an IOException, most systems don't need this much exception handling, and the previous example is exactly the sort of thing that makes your friends who write Ruby code snicker and say somethng like: "Java 10% real code, 90% exception handling".
The example shown below, uses Closeables and Flushables to quietly flush() and close() the OutputStream. If there is an IOException on flush() or close(), your application won't be bothered.

example.title: Using Closeables and Flushables in a finally block

sect2.title: Discussion
sect2.para: While using Closeables and Flushables improves the exception handling situation, is it really that much better? Barely.

Instead of dealing directly with an OutputStream, you can just use the Files class to create a new OutputSupplier. Then, use the ByteStreams class to write a byte array to this OutputSupplier. If you use ByteStreams, you will only have to catch a single occurence of IOException for your call to write(), and ByteStreams will take care of calling close() on the OutputStream.

example.title: Avoid Most Exception Handling with ByteStreams.write()
